message.content: {"facts":["A virtual machine (VM) is a software-based emulation of a physical computer that runs an entire operating system and applications independently of the host system.[1][2][3]","VMs rely on virtualization technology, which allows a single physical server or computer to host multiple virtual environments managed by a hypervisor.[2][5]","Key components of a VM include virtual CPU (vCPU), virtual RAM, virtual hard disk, virtual network interface card (vNIC), and optionally virtual GPU and USB controllers.[1]","The hypervisor manages resource allocation and isolation between VMs and the host hardware, ensuring independent operation.[1][2]","VMs provide multi-tenancy, allowing multiple users or applications to share the same physical hardware securely and efficiently.[4]","Each VM is isolated from others, enhancing security by preventing interference or malware spread between VMs.[4]","VMs are portable and can be transferred between different hardware platforms or cloud environments, facilitating scalability and flexibility.[4]","Resource optimization is a major benefit of VMs, enabling better hardware utilization and cost savings by sharing resources across multiple virtual machines.[4]","VMs enable running multiple operating systems simultaneously on a single physical machine, such as Windows, Linux, or MacOS.[2][3]","VMs are widely used in cloud computing, software development, testing, server consolidation, and running legacy applications.[1][2][3]","Types of virtual machines include system VMs (full OS virtualization) and process VMs (run single applications), as well as specialized forms like desktop virtualization, server virtualization, OS virtualization, and network functions virtualization.[5]","The global virtual machine market size was USD 11.11 billion in 2024 and is projected to grow to USD 12.73 billion in 2025, with a CAGR of 14.71% expected through 2034.[3]","Integration of artificial intelligence (AI) with VMs is increasing, with the global AI market projected to reach USD 826.70 billion by 2030, influencing VM capabilities.[3]","VMs support various network configurations such as bridged, NAT, or host-only modes to provide connectivity.[1]","Virtual machines can emulate hardware components like sound cards, BIOS/UEFI, and timers to provide a realistic computing virtual machine is a fully isolated software emulation of a physical computer running its own OS and applications.","Virtualization technology and hypervisors enable multiple VMs to run concurrently is enhanced through VM isolation, preventing cross-VM interference and malware spread.","VMs are essential in cloud computing, software development, testing, and legacy application support.","There improving data center efficiency.[4]","Virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) solutions use desktop virtualization to provide remote desktop environments to users.[5]","Gaming environments sometimes use
